name: Chloe Bernstein
clarity_response: An app that asks a few questions about your preferences and returns a short list of relevant NYC events and activities happening soon.
strongest_line: You don't need more options. You need the right 3–5, matched to what you actually care about — before they're gone.
weakest_section: Objection handling — reads too defensively, like the product is pre-arguing with me instead of just showing me it works.
what_feels_off: The '87% of people we interviewed' stat feels constructed. I can't verify it and it reads like a startup trying to seem legit.
objections: It's not launched yet. I'm being asked to sign up for something with zero proof it actually delivers good recommendations. I've downloaded three apps like this and deleted them all.
gut_reaction: The headline hits — I am literally the person with 14 tabs open. But I've heard this promise before and I'm not sure what makes this different from Fever or Eventbrite.
unanswered_questions: How does it know what I like if I'm new? What does the onboarding actually look like? How many events are actually in the system right now?
share_trigger: Maybe — if I used it and it actually worked I'd tell my friends, but I wouldn't share a signup link for a product that hasn't launched.

name: Aaliyah Johnson
clarity_response: A recommendation tool that filters NYC events down to a short personalized list based on your category, vibe, budget, and location preferences.
strongest_line: Not a feed. Not 200 results. A shortlist.
weakest_section: Social proof — three quotes from unnamed people and some self-reported survey stats don't actually validate the product works.
what_feels_off: The example recommendation cards feel very curated and perfect. Real recommendations are never this clean. The 'Matched because' explanations feel like they were written to impress, not to reflect how a real algorithm actually works.
objections: I tried Fever and it was gimmicky. This pitch sounds similar. I want proof the recommendations are actually good before I hand over my preferences and get another disappointing shortlist.
gut_reaction: I relate to the problem completely but this sounds like every other app I've already tried. The framing is better than Fever's but I don't see evidence it's actually different.
unanswered_questions: What's the actual data source for events? How does it handle niche requests vs. mainstream ones? What happens if the shortlist is bad — can I give feedback?
share_trigger: No. Not until I've used it for a month and it consistently delivered.

name: Mei-Lin Wu
clarity_response: A filtered recommendation engine that gives you 3–5 personalized NYC event options based on your schedule, budget, and category preferences.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
weakest_section: The 'How It Works' section — three steps sounds easy but I don't trust that the output is actually worth my time without seeing real results from real users.
what_feels_off: I made a Google Sheet of things to do and this feels like a digital version of that. The page doesn't convince me this solves the root problem: the recommendations being genuinely good, not just delivered faster.
objections: It's beta. March 2026. I'd want to wait until there are real reviews and the inventory is actually populated. Being among the first 100 users sounds like being a guinea pig.
gut_reaction: The problem diagnosis is perfect — I feel personally called out. But the solution feels early-stage and I'm worried I'll spend time setting it up and get mediocre results.
unanswered_questions: How many events are actually indexed right now? Is the 'matched because' explanation real or just marketing copy? Will this work for couples?
share_trigger: Only after I've used it and it proved its value. I would not share a cold signup link.

name: Omar Farouk
clarity_response: An app that uses your preferences and filters to surface a short curated list of upcoming NYC events and activities.
strongest_line: Tell us what you're into, when you're free, and how far you'll go. We'll tell you what's worth your time — this week.
weakest_section: The stats section — '87% of people we interviewed' is not a convincing number when you're the one doing the interviewing.
what_feels_off: The phrase 'help shape what NYC event discovery looks like' in the CTA is founder-y. I don't want to shape anything. I just want good recommendations.
objections: Price sensitivity is real — I want to know whether it works before I commit any mental energy to onboarding. I've sent options to group chats that got zero response. Will this actually get people to show up?
gut_reaction: As the guy who always sends options to the group chat, I actually want this. The example cards are useful. I'd sign up but I'm not excited about being a beta user.
unanswered_questions: Does it handle group logistics — like finding one thing multiple people will all show up for? Can I share the shortlist directly to a group chat?
share_trigger: Yes, actually — if this worked well I'd absolutely send it to my friend group. That's my whole use case.

name: Tamika Harris
clarity_response: A personalized event recommendation app for NYC that filters thousands of options down to 3–5 relevant things to do based on your preferences.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: Objection handling — reading it felt like the company is more worried about objections than confident in their product.
what_feels_off: I subscribe to four NYC newsletters and I still miss things. This feels like another newsletter with extra steps. The page doesn't explain why this is structurally different.
objections: I've trained myself to ignore things I sign up for before they launch. Beta in March 2026 is too vague. I'll forget about this by next week.
gut_reaction: The problem is real and the framing is sharper than most apps. But I need to see it work — not just read that it works.
unanswered_questions: What keeps me coming back after the first shortlist? Is there a habit loop or is this a one-time use thing? What happens to my data?
share_trigger: Not yet. I'd need to use it first.

name: Keiko Yamamoto
clarity_response: An app that filters NYC events into a short personalized list based on category, timing, budget, and distance preferences.
strongest_line: Not a feed. Not 200 results. A shortlist.
weakest_section: The example recommendation cards — they're all very art/indie/cultural. Where's the couple-friendly date night option beyond the piano night card?
what_feels_off: The ClassPass comparison implicitly made on the page feels stretched. ClassPass has massive inventory. An unproven beta app promising similar discovery is a big leap.
objections: I want couple-friendly activity suggestions and the page barely addresses that use case. The examples skew solo or group. I also don't see how this handles two people with different tastes.
gut_reaction: I like the concept and I'd want it to be real, but March 2026 beta with no social proof from actual users makes me hesitant.
unanswered_questions: Can two people set filters together? Does it work for date nights specifically? How does it handle different budgets in a couple?
share_trigger: Maybe — I'd want to try it first before recommending it to anyone.

name: Liam O'Brien
clarity_response: A short-list recommendation app for NYC events and activities that filters by category, schedule, budget, and distance.
strongest_line: The mental load before the fun.
weakest_section: Social proof — three user quotes and self-reported interview data doesn't tell me anything about whether the product actually works.
what_feels_off: The page says 'we track' pop-ups and time-limited events but provides zero evidence of how or how comprehensively. That's a big claim with no support.
objections: Media planner in me notices there's no real social proof here. Quotes from people who described the problem, not people who used and loved the solution. That gap bothers me.
gut_reaction: Good problem framing, competent copy. But I'm skeptical because there are zero testimonials from people who actually used this product.
unanswered_questions: What's the actual event database sourced from? Is there editorial curation or purely algorithmic filtering? Who's behind this?
share_trigger: No. Nothing to share yet — the product doesn't exist.

name: Jenna Liu
clarity_response: An event recommendation app that returns a short personalized list of NYC activities based on your preferences, schedule, and budget.
strongest_line: By the time I find out about it, it's already over.
weakest_section: The objection handling section — it's too long and reads like the founders are anxious. It made me think of objections I hadn't even had.
what_feels_off: The Williamsburg location in the example cards feels targeted. A little too much like someone tried to appeal to my demographic.
objections: I tried Fever and found it gimmicky. I don't understand what makes this genuinely better other than fewer results. Quality isn't just about quantity.
gut_reaction: It's speaking my language and I'm interested. But it's a beta and I've been burned before. I'd sign up if it cost me nothing and required no effort.
unanswered_questions: How often does the shortlist refresh? Daily, weekly, on demand? Is there a Thursday shortlist feature or is that aspirational?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd share — this is exactly the kind of app my friend group would use if it actually worked.

name: Ethan Nakamura
clarity_response: A NYC event discovery tool that filters events by personal preferences and returns a short curated shortlist instead of overwhelming results.
strongest_line: You don't need more options. You need the right 3–5.
weakest_section: The stats — '6 out of 10 said they've given up' is based on the team's own interviews, which is circular validation.
what_feels_off: I made a stale Google Sheet trying to solve this myself. This page describes that frustration perfectly but doesn't tell me why the recommendations won't also go stale.
objections: I'm a content strategist — I know good copy from manipulative copy. This is good copy. But I don't see proof the product is as good as the copy.
gut_reaction: Strong copy, correctly identifies my problem. But as someone who writes content for a living, I'm aware this page was designed to convert me and I'm resistant to that.
unanswered_questions: How is the event data maintained and kept current? Who reviews recommendation quality? Is there a feedback loop?
share_trigger: I'd share the concept but not the signup link. Concepts are shareable. Beta signups are not.

name: Lucia Ferraro
clarity_response: An app that filters NYC events and activities down to a personalized shortlist of 3–5 options based on preferences, schedule, and budget.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
weakest_section: The CTA body copy — 'help shape what NYC event discovery looks like' sounds like startup marketing speak, not a user benefit.
what_feels_off: As an event coordinator I'm suspicious about how comprehensive the event data actually is. The 'Kehinde Wiley: New Portraits' example feels researched rather than algorithmically surfaced.
objections: I want to know: is the event data actually comprehensive, or will it surface the same mainstream events I already see everywhere? My job requires me to know about things before they go viral.
gut_reaction: This is the app I wish existed. But I've coordinated enough events to know how hard it is to maintain current, comprehensive data across NYC categories.
unanswered_questions: How are events submitted to the platform? Is there a way for event organizers to add events? How do you handle the Long Island City and outer-borough coverage?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd share this with my whole network if it actually worked — this is a tool I'd use professionally.

name: Theo Papadopoulos
clarity_response: A NYC event recommendation app that cuts through platform fragmentation by delivering a short filtered list based on stated preferences.
strongest_line: One app instead of six.
weakest_section: The social proof — these quotes are from interviews validating the problem, not from users validating the solution. That's a critical gap.
what_feels_off: Digital marketing background makes me notice: no actual product screenshots, no app store link, no waitlist count, no demo. This is pure promise.
objections: I'm being asked to give trust to an unproven beta app. Every marketing analyst instinct I have says this is too early to sign up for. Wait until it's real.
gut_reaction: Problem is real, copy is decent, but there is genuinely zero product proof here. I'd rather wait for a friend to tell me it works.
unanswered_questions: Is there an actual product? When does it launch? What does onboarding look like? Is there a demo I can see?
share_trigger: No. I'd share it when I've used it and it's good. Not now.

name: Danielle Brooks
clarity_response: A filtered event shortlist app for NYC that personalizes results to your preferences, schedule, and budget.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: Objection handling — as a copywriter, this section reads like anxiety. Too many objections anticipated, not enough confidence.
what_feels_off: The copy is good but a little too self-aware. The 'point isn't more listings — it's less time deciding' line sounds like it was written by someone who knows they're writing copy. Which I am, so it put me off slightly.
objections: It's beta and doesn't exist yet. I know how these things go — I might sign up and hear nothing for months.
gut_reaction: Very relatable problem, competent copy, but as a professional copywriter I'm harder to convert by good copy alone. Show me the product.
unanswered_questions: What does the interface actually look like? Is this a web app or mobile? How does it handle recurring use — does the shortlist change every week?
share_trigger: Maybe. If I used it and the UX was as clean as the landing page copy suggests, I'd share it.

name: Elena Petrov
clarity_response: An app that recommends a few personalized NYC events each week based on your preferences so you don't default to the same places.
strongest_line: Still going to the same three places every weekend?
weakest_section: The example cards — three of the five are culture/art-adjacent. I go out 4–5 nights a week. Where's nightlife in those examples?
what_feels_off: The candlelit piano night card is not what I'm looking for. The examples feel like they're targeting someone older and quieter than me.
objections: I go out a lot but I'm not an art exhibition person. The examples in the 'How It Works' section make me wonder if the recommendations will actually match my vibe or just be generic cultural events.
gut_reaction: The headline called me out immediately. But I'm worried this is for people who want art galleries, not for people who want a good bar they haven't tried yet.
unanswered_questions: Does it cover pure nightlife? Bars? Concerts at small venues? Or is it mostly art and activities?
share_trigger: If it covered nightlife well, absolutely — my whole group has this problem.

name: Amira Khalil
clarity_response: A shortlist recommendation app that surfaces 3–5 relevant NYC events based on your stated preferences and constraints.
strongest_line: By the time I find out about it, it's already over.
weakest_section: The social proof numbers feel self-reported and circular. The team interviewed 50+ people, found they had this problem, and now that's the social proof. That's not the same as user validation.
what_feels_off: As a spin instructor I hear people talk about wanting to explore the city all the time. But every app promises this. The skeptic in me asks: what's the failure mode?
objections: Skepticism level 4. I want to know what happens when the recommendations are bad. There's no accountability mechanism described. If the shortlist is lame three weeks in a row, what do I do?
gut_reaction: I've been the social connector who keeps recommending the East Village bars. This would genuinely help me. But I need to know it works before I tell my clients about it.
unanswered_questions: Is there a feedback mechanism? Can I say 'this wasn't for me' and have it actually learn? What borough coverage is like beyond Manhattan?
share_trigger: If it worked consistently I would share it with my whole class roster. But not before.

name: Darius Jackson
clarity_response: An app that recommends 3–5 personalized NYC things to do each week based on your preferences, budget, and location.
strongest_line: Still going to the same three places every weekend?
weakest_section: The privacy/no social feed section in objection handling — I don't care about that. I want to know if the recommendations are actually fun.
what_feels_off: The 'first 100 users get early access' creates artificial urgency that feels a little cheap. But it works on me which is annoying.
objections: I tried a 'new thing every week' challenge with friends and it lasted 3 weeks. What makes this different? I need the app to make it easy enough that I'll actually go through with it.
gut_reaction: I'm the one who plans and I never plan anything actually new. This is exactly for me. Low skepticism so I'll probably sign up.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle multiple people with different tastes? Can I share the shortlist with a group? Is there a social component?
share_trigger: Yes, immediately — I'd send this to my friends right now.

name: Natasha Ivanova
clarity_response: A personalized NYC event shortlist that filters recommendations to what you actually want to do this week.
strongest_line: Tell us what you're into, when you're free, and how far you'll go.
weakest_section: The stats section — those numbers feel like startup validation, not credibility.
what_feels_off: Nothing major. Low skepticism. But the page is a little long. By the time I got to the objection handling I was already decided.
objections: Minor ones — does it work for spontaneous plans or only if I know in advance I want to go out?
gut_reaction: I say 'let's do something different' every Saturday and then end up at brunch. This promises to solve exactly that. I'm signing up.
unanswered_questions: Is it just a web signup or is there actually an app? How do I get the shortlist — email, push notification, or in-app?
share_trigger: Yes, this is exactly the thing I'd send to my friend group on a Thursday.

name: Marcus Thompson
clarity_response: An app that filters NYC events into a personalized shortlist based on your preferences.
strongest_line: Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: The social proof section — three quotes from unnamed people and some stats don't tell me anything useful as a bartender who sees what people actually want on weekends.
what_feels_off: I follow NYC lifestyle accounts and rarely act on their posts. This feels like another version of that — good-looking content with no follow-through mechanism.
objections: I live in the LES and know it cold. A shortlist of 3–5 events won't replace knowing a place. And the example cards (Chelsea gallery, UWS piano) feel out of my neighborhood range.
gut_reaction: I'm skeptical of apps that promise to tell me what's good. I already know my area. This might be more useful for someone newer to the city.
unanswered_questions: How hyperlocal is this? Can I filter to within 5 blocks? Does it cover the kinds of events I actually care about — underground parties, low-key concerts?
share_trigger: No. Not until I've used it.

name: Morgan Reilly
clarity_response: A filtered shortlist app for NYC events that matches recommendations to your preferences and constraints.
strongest_line: Spend less time planning, more time doing.
weakest_section: The objection handling — felt unnecessary. I was already sold before reaching it.
what_feels_off: The daytime event examples (foraging walk, candlelit piano) are actually perfect for my use case. But the nightlife example felt tacked on. I want more daytime options since I'm trying to shift away from nightlife.
objections: Low skepticism. Main concern is whether it covers daytime activities and fitness-adjacent events or just nightlife and art.
gut_reaction: I'm trying to shift from nightlife to daytime activities and the foraging walk example is literally what I want. I'm signing up.
unanswered_questions: How much daytime vs nightlife content is there? Does it cover fitness events like run clubs and outdoor workouts?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd tell my fitness clients about this immediately.

name: Yusuf Abdi
clarity_response: An NYC event discovery app that cuts recommendations down to a short personalized shortlist.
strongest_line: Not a feed. Not 200 results.
weakest_section: Social proof — interview data from the team's own research isn't third-party validation.
what_feels_off: I manage a restaurant. I see apps like this pitched all the time. The 'aggregates across sources' claim is the hard part nobody actually delivers on. This page doesn't address the data sourcing challenge honestly.
objections: The product is unproven and beta. As a restaurant manager I know event data is messy, changes constantly, and requires real operational infrastructure to maintain. I don't see any evidence this team has that.
gut_reaction: Concept is right. Execution is unproven. I'd wait and see.
unanswered_questions: How is event data sourced and kept current? Who's verifying it? How many events are actually in the system now?
share_trigger: No. Not at this stage.

name: Gabrielle Moreau
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity recommender that cuts through discovery overwhelm by giving you a short, filtered shortlist.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
weakest_section: The example cards — as a Chelsea resident the examples are actually relevant to me, but the outer-borough card (LIC Afrobeats) felt like it was inserted specifically for demographic breadth.
what_feels_off: I'm a real estate agent. I know every neighborhood. The 'distance filter' claim is appealing but I want to know if the recommendations change meaningfully based on location input or if they're just Manhattan-centric.
objections: Is this actually citywide or is it mostly Manhattan? The example cards include one LIC event but that feels token.
gut_reaction: I have enough energy Saturday morning but by 2pm I'm back at brunch. This addresses exactly that. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Does the distance filter actually work for Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx? How comprehensive is outer-borough coverage?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd share this in my client groups — people always ask me what to do on weekends.

name: Fatima Al-Hassan
clarity_response: An app that recommends a short personalized list of NYC events based on your filters and preferences.
strongest_line: Still going to the same three places every weekend?
weakest_section: The objection handling — as someone with high skepticism I found the answers too quick and confident for a product that hasn't launched yet.
what_feels_off: The 'new thing every week challenge with friends that lasted 3 weeks' is essentially my story. But an app doesn't fix the underlying behavior problem. The page doesn't address consistency or habit formation.
objections: I've tried challenges, apps, everything. The problem isn't finding options, it's actually going. This product addresses discovery but not follow-through. I'm not convinced the shortlist changes my behavior.
gut_reaction: Concept sounds good but I've been burned by 'this will finally fix my routine' promises before. High skepticism. Show me the product first.
unanswered_questions: What's the behavior change mechanism? Is there anything that helps you actually follow through and go, or is it just a prettier list?
share_trigger: No. Not yet.

name: Aisha Rahman
clarity_response: A NYC event shortlist app that filters recommendations down to a few relevant options based on your preferences and schedule.
strongest_line: I didn't know this thing existed. I would do it as long as they tell me these things exist.
weakest_section: The stats section — I skimmed past it. It doesn't add much.
what_feels_off: Nothing really. Low skepticism, works irregular hours so spontaneous discovery is genuinely valuable to me.
objections: Not many. I'd like to know if it handles last-minute plans or if I need to plan in advance.
gut_reaction: This is what I've been looking for. I know there's cool stuff happening but I never hear about it in time. Signing up.
unanswered_questions: Does it work for tonight, or is it more of a weekend-planning tool? How last-minute can the recommendations be?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd share this right now.

name: Jake Rosenberg
clarity_response: A shortlist recommendation tool for NYC events based on personal preference filters.
strongest_line: Not a feed. Not 200 results. A shortlist.
weakest_section: Social proof — the quotes validate the problem, not the product. There are no testimonials from people who actually used this app.
what_feels_off: I follow NYC lifestyle accounts and rarely act on them. I'm aware of the pattern. An app that sends a shortlist is still just another thing I'll passively receive and not act on.
objections: Having lived here 4+ years, I know my neighborhood well and rarely need help. The pitch is aimed at people newer to the city or less established. I'm not sure this is actually for me.
gut_reaction: I plan everything and never plan anything new. But I've been here long enough that I'm honestly bored of the new thing concept. This might be more useful for someone still discovering the city.
unanswered_questions: How niche does it get? If I know most of Manhattan, does it surface things I genuinely haven't heard of, or just more mainstream events?
share_trigger: Unlikely. I'd evaluate it first.

name: Renée Dubois
clarity_response: An app that recommends 3–5 relevant NYC activities based on your preferences, timing, budget, and location.
strongest_line: Still going to the same three places every weekend?
weakest_section: The 'built from conversations with 50+ New Yorkers' headline for social proof — this is problem validation, not product validation.
what_feels_off: The example cards are all pretty upscale or culturally sophisticated — gallery shows, piano nights, rooftop parties. As a hair stylist in Washington Heights I wonder if the recommendations will reflect my neighborhood and budget.
objections: I want to know if this works for Washington Heights or if it's Manhattan-centric. The examples are mostly Manhattan and LIC. I have a 'someday' list that never becomes 'this weekend' and I'm not sure a shortlist alone changes that.
gut_reaction: I'm interested but cautious. I have all this energy on Saturday that disappears by 2pm. Whether this app can interrupt that pattern depends on how relevant the results actually are.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle upper Manhattan and neighborhoods outside the typical Brooklyn-Lower Manhattan circuit? Does it cover community-specific events?
share_trigger: Maybe. If the recommendations felt relevant to my neighborhood I'd tell my clients.

name: Andre Williams
clarity_response: An event recommendation app that filters NYC options down to a short personalized list based on your preferences.
strongest_line: Not a feed. Not 200 results. A shortlist.
weakest_section: The 'How It Works' section — three steps sounds simple but doesn't tell me anything about the quality or specificity of the output.
what_feels_off: I have a private Google Maps list of 40 pins I've personally curated. This app is essentially promising to do what I do for myself, but automated. That skepticism is real: algorithmic curation has never matched personal curation for me.
objections: I don't need more options. I need better ones. The page never convincingly answers how the recommendation quality is ensured. I've tried apps that promise curated results and got garbage.
gut_reaction: I appreciate brevity — 3–5 is the right number. But the page feels like it's designed for the overwhelmed mainstream crowd, not for people like me who are already selective and just want a signal boost.
unanswered_questions: How do you ensure recommendation quality vs. just showing me things that haven't sold out? Is there editorial oversight or purely algorithmic?
share_trigger: No. I keep my list to myself. This app would have to earn my trust first.

name: Kira Johansson
clarity_response: A personalized shortlist app for NYC events and activities that filters by category, budget, schedule, and distance.
strongest_line: We never use your social feed. Your preferences stay private.
weakest_section: The social proof section — built on 50+ interviews by the founders themselves. That's not independent validation.
what_feels_off: I went to a viral TikTok bar once and regretted it immediately. This page promises the opposite but the example cards (rooftop Afrobeats party, comedy lottery) could easily appear on TikTok. The curation ethos isn't clear.
objections: The page doesn't convince me the recommendations will be genuinely low-key and niche vs. just slightly less mainstream. I need to trust the taste behind the curation and I have zero basis for that trust.
dealbreaker_reason: No evidence the recommendation quality matches my preferences for non-viral, non-mainstream, quiet experiences. The page's own examples include rooftop parties and comedy lottery events — exactly the kind of mass-appeal events I avoid.
gut_reaction: If it went viral on TikTok, I'd be immediately suspicious. And this product might go viral. I'm not sure I want my recommendations coming from an app that anyone can use.
unanswered_questions: Is there a way to filter for genuinely niche, under-the-radar things vs. events that are just less mainstream? Who decides what's worth knowing about?
share_trigger: Absolutely not. That would defeat the point entirely.

name: Adrienne Cole
clarity_response: A filtered NYC event recommendation tool that returns a short personalized list based on stated preferences instead of passive algorithmic feeds.
strongest_line: The mental load before the fun is the actual problem. The fun part is fine.
weakest_section: Objection handling — as a UX researcher I notice the page frontloads objection responses. Good UX would surface this differently. Also the objection answers are slightly defensive.
what_feels_off: The 'matched because' explanations in the example cards are doing a lot of heavy lifting. In reality, algorithmic explanations for recommendations are often post-hoc rationalizations, not actual reasoning. That bothers me.
objections: Skepticism level 5. I trust exactly 3 friends for recommendations. An app is not a friend. I need to understand the editorial judgment behind it before trusting its output.
gut_reaction: Problem diagnosis is spot on. The mental load is the issue. But as a UX researcher I would need to evaluate the actual product before forming a real opinion.
unanswered_questions: What does the actual filtering UI look like? How granular are the category filters? Can I filter for things I've never done before vs. things similar to what I've done?
share_trigger: No. I'd evaluate it myself first with methodical testing before recommending to anyone.

name: Olivia Santos
clarity_response: An app that filters NYC events by personal preferences and returns a short curated shortlist.
strongest_line: We never use your social feed. Your preferences stay private.
weakest_section: The entire 'How It Works' section — it describes inputs and outputs but says nothing about how the quality of the recommendation is evaluated or ensured.
what_feels_off: I research a restaurant for 20 minutes before going. This app is asking me to trust its curation with 3 filters in 2 minutes. That's not how I make decisions. The speed pitch is actually a red flag for me.
objections: The pitch is designed for high-volume decision paralysis. My problem is different — I'm selective and willing to do the research. I don't want fewer options; I want confident confidence in the one option I pick.
gut_reaction: I'd rather go to one great place than bounce between three mediocre ones. This app might solve the wrong version of my problem.
unanswered_questions: Is there a quality signal beyond 'it matched your filters'? Are events rated or vetted in any way? Can I see reviews before deciding?
share_trigger: No.

name: Tara Patel
clarity_response: A NYC event shortlist tool that delivers personalized recommendations based on preference filters without relying on social media.
strongest_line: We never use your social feed. Your preferences stay private.
weakest_section: Social proof — the quotes are from people describing the problem, not from people who found a solution. The section validates the market but not the product.
what_feels_off: I deleted Instagram specifically to reduce noise. This page's CTA opens a signup form that requires an email. The next step is: get emails from this startup. That's not obviously better than Instagram noise.
objections: I rely on Google Maps and one trusted newsletter. I'd need to be convinced this is as reliably trustworthy as those before adding it to my life. 'Beta' is the opposite of that reassurance.
gut_reaction: The privacy angle genuinely appeals to me. But signing up for beta means becoming a tester, and I want a finished product.
unanswered_questions: What is the email communication like after signup? How many emails will I get? Can I opt out of notifications entirely and just open it when I want?
share_trigger: No. I'm protective of the tools I use. I don't casually recommend things.

name: Raj Patel
clarity_response: A NYC event recommendation app that filters by preference to return a short personalized shortlist.
strongest_line: Zero rabbit holes.
weakest_section: The example recommendation cards — the rooftop Afrobeats party and late-night comedy lottery are not my idea of quality. They're popular, not good. This signals mass-market taste.
what_feels_off: I have strong opinions about which neighborhoods are real vs. tourist traps. An app that 'aggregates from everywhere' could easily surface overpriced tourist events alongside genuine gems. No filtering mechanism is described for quality vs. popularity.
objections: I trust very few sources. This app has no track record. The example events include things I'd actively avoid. The curation philosophy is not articulated.
dealbreaker_reason: The examples suggest the app surfaces mainstream and popular events. For a quiet explorer who wants genuinely niche, low-key, non-viral experiences, this doesn't seem designed for me. The rooftop party example was the dealbreaker.
gut_reaction: If it went viral on TikTok, I'm already suspicious. And this app itself could go viral, which would mean the recommendations trend popular rather than quality.
unanswered_questions: Is there any mechanism to filter by obscurity, intimacy, or anti-trend? How does it distinguish between 'good' and 'popular'?
share_trigger: No. I don't share things like this.

name: Simone Baptiste
clarity_response: A personalized NYC event shortlist tool that uses preference filters instead of social media to surface relevant things to do.
strongest_line: The mental load before the fun is the actual problem. The fun part is fine.
weakest_section: The objection handling section — too long and reveals insecurity. A confident product doesn't need to pre-answer every possible objection on its homepage.
what_feels_off: I have a private Google Maps list I've never told anyone about. This app would expose my taste patterns to a company's algorithm. That's a different thing from private curation and the page glosses over it.
objections: High skepticism. I'm a backend developer — I know how recommendation systems actually work and how often they fail for niche users. This page describes the intended behavior, not the actual behavior.
gut_reaction: The mental load framing is exactly right. But as someone who values privacy and curation quality, I'd need a much longer evaluation before trusting this.
unanswered_questions: What data is retained after I use it? How are preferences stored? Is there a way to export or delete my data?
share_trigger: No. My recommendations to friends are curated and personal. An app recommendation would undercut that.

name: Jamal Carter
clarity_response: An NYC event recommendation app that filters options down to a short personalized list based on stated preferences.
strongest_line: We never use your social feed. Your preferences stay private.
weakest_section: The example cards — I went to a viral TikTok bar once and regretted it. The rooftop Afrobeats party example feels like it could easily be that same experience.
what_feels_off: The page promises niche and non-mainstream options but the example events include things I've seen promoted on mainstream Instagram. The gap between promise and example erodes trust.
objections: I value solitude and quality over volume. I'd rather go to one great place. The 3–5 options pitch only helps if those 3–5 are genuinely excellent — and there's no evidence mechanism for that.
gut_reaction: I appreciate the 'no social feed' promise. But I need to know the recommendation quality is actually good for someone who prefers quiet, non-viral experiences.
unanswered_questions: Is there a filter for crowd size, intimacy, or vibe (quiet vs. energetic)? The category filters listed don't address atmosphere.
share_trigger: No. I evaluate things for myself first.

name: Diana Tran
clarity_response: A filtered NYC event recommendation tool that delivers a short personalized shortlist based on your categories, schedule, and preferences.
strongest_line: I don't need more options. I need someone to just tell me the 2 good ones.
weakest_section: The social proof section — completely based on the team's own research. Technically it validates the market, but it's not independent validation and I notice that.
what_feels_off: I trust exactly 3 friends for recommendations. This app cannot replicate that trust relationship. The page uses social proof language ('built from conversations with 50+ New Yorkers') to simulate it but it's not the same.
objections: I moved to NYC for work and I'm still building a social circle. I need recommendations I can actually trust, and this startup hasn't earned that yet. Beta status makes it worse.
gut_reaction: The core idea is exactly what I want. But trust is slow-built and a beta app can't start there.
unanswered_questions: How does the quality of the shortlist compare to a trusted friend's recommendation? What's the percentage of 'good recommendations' based on real user feedback?
share_trigger: No. I don't casually recommend things.

name: Nina Aleksandrov
clarity_response: A NYC event shortlist app that personalizes recommendations to your preferences and filters out irrelevant noise.
strongest_line: We never use your social feed. Your preferences stay private.
weakest_section: The stats — '87% of people we interviewed use 3+ platforms.' The team interviewed people for product research, not to generate marketing stats. The data point is circular.
what_feels_off: As a librarian I appreciate good information architecture. The example recommendation cards show good metadata (location, timing, price, reason) but the page doesn't explain how complete or reliable that data actually is.
objections: Lower skepticism but I want to know about data quality and completeness. I research things before going — will the 'why it matched you' explanation actually be meaningful or generic?
gut_reaction: I'm in a long-term relationship and looking for low-key date activities. The candlelit piano card is almost too on the nose. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: How detailed is the event metadata? Hours, accessibility, indoor/outdoor, crowd size? Will there be enough for date nights specifically?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd recommend this to friends who ask what to do on weekends — which is often.

name: Ben Shapiro-Stein
clarity_response: A filtered NYC event recommendation engine that returns a short personalized shortlist based on stated preferences.
strongest_line: The mental load before the fun is the actual problem. The fun part is fine.
weakest_section: Objection handling — way too long for the page position. By the time I hit section 4, the page has lost momentum. Cut it by half.
what_feels_off: As an architect who works remotely, weekends are my main social outlet and I've deleted Instagram. I need recommendations I trust, not ones that feel designed to be shareable. The page feels slightly consumer-marketing-brained.
objections: Skepticism 5. I'd want to understand the editorial curation philosophy before trusting any recommendation this app makes. The page doesn't articulate this at all.
gut_reaction: Correct diagnosis. The mental load is the problem. But I'd need to actually use it before believing the cure works.
unanswered_questions: Is there human editorial involvement in what gets recommended, or is it purely categorical filtering? What's the standard for 'worth knowing about'?
share_trigger: No. I evaluate things carefully before recommending them.

name: Sade Adeyemi
clarity_response: A NYC activity recommendation tool that returns a short personalized list based on your stated preferences rather than passive social feeds.
strongest_line: We never use your social feed. Your preferences stay private.
weakest_section: The example cards — I want to know if it covers museums, reading events, and quiet neighborhood things. The cards skew toward evening events.
what_feels_off: I'd rather go to one great place than bounce between three mediocre ones. The promise of 3–5 options only works if all five are good. The page doesn't explain how that's guaranteed.
objections: Lower skepticism but I want quality over quantity. The app seems designed for people who need volume reduced. I need quality elevated. Different problem.
gut_reaction: I want this to work for my use case — reading events, museum programming, quiet neighborhood things. Cautiously interested.
unanswered_questions: How deep does the cultural programming coverage go? Book talks, lectures, neighborhood events? Or mostly nightlife and art gallery openings?
share_trigger: Maybe, if it proved useful for my specific taste profile.

name: Rachel Park
clarity_response: An NYC event discovery app that surfaces time-sensitive and niche cultural events in a personalized shortlist based on your preferences.
strongest_line: By the time I find out about it, it's already over.
weakest_section: The stats section — I don't need to be convinced the problem exists. Tell me more about the event coverage, specifically cultural programming.
what_feels_off: The Kehinde Wiley example card is perfect but I wonder if it's cherry-picked. What does average cultural programming coverage look like? I need to trust the depth before I trust the shortlist.
objections: Is the gallery and exhibition coverage actually comprehensive? I discover exhibitions through Instagram stories and find out they're closing. I need something with better coverage than Instagram. Is that actually what this is?
gut_reaction: I didn't know this thing existed and I would have gone if someone told me. This is for me. I'm signing up immediately.
unanswered_questions: How deep is the gallery and exhibition coverage? Are there MoMA, Whitney, Guggenheim programs? What about pop-up shows in artist studios?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd share immediately with everyone in my network who cares about art.

name: Tomás Guerrero
clarity_response: A personalized NYC event shortlist that surfaces cultural and time-limited events matched to your preferences.
strongest_line: If it has a date and it's worth knowing about, it should be here.
weakest_section: The objection handling — as someone who moved to NYC for the cultural scene, I didn't have these objections. The section felt like it was talking to a different kind of user.
what_feels_off: Nothing major. Low skepticism. The Van Gogh comparison in my head makes me wonder if this only covers immersive, ticketed experiences or also smaller gallery shows.
objections: Minimal. Just want to know the coverage is genuinely comprehensive for immersive and gallery experiences, not just mainstream ticketed events.
gut_reaction: I moved here for this exact kind of discovery. Why do I always find out about cool things the day they close? This solves that.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle free gallery shows vs. ticketed immersive experiences? Does it cover both?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd share this across every creative professional group I'm in.

name: Zara Osei
clarity_response: A NYC event recommendation app that actively curates a personalized shortlist of cultural and time-limited events based on your preferences.
strongest_line: Instagram is random. I want to actively search for what's happening, not wait for the algorithm.
weakest_section: The stats — I already know the problem exists intimately. I don't need data convincing me.
what_feels_off: I follow 30+ NYC culture accounts and still miss things. The information overload point is real. But the page says 'we track' pop-ups without explaining the mechanism. That's the critical gap.
objections: As a gallery assistant I know how inconsistent event listing data is. Many pop-ups and smaller shows don't have Eventbrite pages. How does this actually get that data?
gut_reaction: This is Instagram but intentional. I want this so badly. The question is whether the data coverage actually reaches the niche things I care about.
unanswered_questions: What's the data source for smaller gallery shows and pop-ups that don't list on major platforms? Is there an editorial team or crowdsourced submissions?
share_trigger: Yes, immediately — everyone I work with would use this.

name: Esme Blackwell
clarity_response: A NYC event shortlist app that filters recommendations to match your taste profile and surfaces time-limited events.
strongest_line: I want to be the person who knows about the pop-up before everyone else.
weakest_section: The objection handling — felt generic. It addressed common objections but not the specific concern of a culture-first user: recommendation quality and exclusivity.
what_feels_off: I tried Time Out NYC and found it too broad. The page positions against Eventbrite and Fever but doesn't differentiate from Time Out, which is actually my reference point.
objections: Does this actually surface exclusive, ahead-of-trend things? Or will it show me what everyone else already knows about? The fashion buyer in me wants to know first, not same time as everyone.
gut_reaction: High skepticism but the pop-up tracking angle genuinely interests me. I want to know about the sample sale before Instagram.
unanswered_questions: Is there a 'first to know' or 'ending soon' filter? How early in an event's lifecycle does it appear in the system?
share_trigger: Only if I found it delivered on the exclusivity promise. Not just another discovery app.

name: Nikolai Volkov
clarity_response: A NYC event recommendation tool that curates a personalized shortlist based on your preferences and surfaces time-limited cultural events.
strongest_line: Exhibitions ending this week, sample sales, limited-run shows, neighborhood pop-ups.
weakest_section: Social proof — built from interview data, not product testimonials.
what_feels_off: I have a friend who always knows about pop-ups. I wish I could replicate that knowledge. This app promises the same thing but I'm skeptical the data depth is there. A friend sources from real relationships; an app sources from... what?
objections: I need to know the pop-up and gallery coverage is actually better than what I already get from following the right Instagram accounts. What's the information advantage?
gut_reaction: I want to replicate my well-connected friend's knowledge at scale. If this app can do that, I'm in. If it's just Eventbrite with a better UI, I'm not.
unanswered_questions: What's the unique data advantage vs. following 30 culture accounts on Instagram? How is the content sourced that doesn't appear on mainstream platforms?
share_trigger: If it delivered, yes — I have a whole creative network who would love this.

name: Courtney Ng

objections: The coverage depth question is real. My beat requires me to know what's happening culturally. If this misses things, it's not a helpful signal — it's a false sense of confidence.
gut_reaction: Why do I always find out about cool things the day they close? That exact pain is why I want this. I'd sign up today.

name: Priya Nair
clarity_response: A personalized event shortlist for NYC that focuses on discovering time-limited cultural events before they end.
strongest_line: I didn't know this thing existed. I would do it as long as they tell me these things exist.

what_feels_off: I follow 30+ NYC culture accounts and still miss things. Adding another input to my discovery ecosystem isn't clearly better than restructuring my approach to the 30 I have. The page doesn't make the case for why this is different structurally.
objections: As a photographer I want to know about photo exhibitions, open studios, and portfolio events. The category list doesn't include anything photography-specific and that gaps my trust.

unanswered_questions: Does the category list include photography, film screenings, or open studio events? The category options on the page feel generic.

name: Ravi Krishnan

unanswered_questions: What's the editorial quality control for what gets tagged as 'worth knowing about'? Is there a taste layer or just aggregation?

name: Paloma Cruz
clarity_response: A NYC event shortlist app that personalizes cultural and time-limited event recommendations based on stated preferences.

name: Yara Nazari
clarity_response: A personalized NYC event discovery app that surfaces time-limited cultural events before they close.
strongest_line: By the time I find out about it, it's already over.

name: Nkechi Okafor
clarity_response: A NYC event recommendation app that filters events to match your preferences, budget, and schedule.
strongest_line: Free only, under $20, or no limit? We filter so you don't have to.
weakest_section: The example cards — the cheapest option shown is $10 comedy, $15 rooftop, $18 piano. Where's the actually free stuff? The foraging walk example is helpful but one free example out of five sends the wrong signal.
what_feels_off: The app is 'free to use' but the events shown cost $10–$18. For someone recently moved to NYC adjusting to the cost of everything, this page needs more free event representation.
objections: The free filter is there, which is good. But the example cards skew toward paid events and I don't have confidence the free content is actually good. I Googled 'free things to do in NYC' and got 200 random events, half expired. Is this just a prettier version of that?
gut_reaction: The budget filter is exactly what I need. But I need to see more free examples to believe the free content is high quality and current.
unanswered_questions: How many of the shortlist events are free on any given week? What percentage of the event inventory is free?
share_trigger: If the free event coverage was genuinely good, yes — all my friends are in the same budget situation.

name: David Kim
clarity_response: A NYC event shortlist app that filters events by category, schedule, budget, and distance.
strongest_line: Free only, under $20, or no limit? We filter so you don't have to.
weakest_section: The social proof section — quotes from the team's own research. No independent validation.
what_feels_off: I went to a 'free' event that turned out to be a sales pitch with a cash bar. This page says free events are included but doesn't explain how they're vetted for actually being free and worth going to. 'Free in NYC usually means not actually fun' is my lived experience.
objections: High skepticism about the quality of free recommendations specifically. The budget filter is right but quality control for free events is the hard part. Does this actually surface legitimately good free things?
gut_reaction: The budget filter is the headline feature for me. But without evidence the free content is high quality, I'm not convinced this is better than my current approach.
unanswered_questions: How does it quality-screen free events? Is there any vetting or is it purely listing aggregation?
share_trigger: Only if it proved the free content was actually good.

name: Hannah Kim
clarity_response: A free-to-use NYC event recommendation app that filters to a short personalized shortlist based on budget and preferences.

weakest_section: The stats section — I don't need stats, I just need to know there's quality free content.

objections: I want to know: if I select 'free only,' does the shortlist quality hold? Or do I get the leftover events nobody else wanted?
gut_reaction: My friends always want to go to $20-cover bars. I just want something that doesn't cost anything. This app might help me be the one who suggests the good free option for once.
unanswered_questions: If I always filter to free, how often does the shortlist have 3–5 good options vs. fewer? Is there enough free content to sustain weekly use?
share_trigger: Yes, if the free content was solid, I'd send this to all my budget-conscious friends.

name: Kwame Asante

objections: Budget is the filter I care about most. I need to know the under-$20 and free content is actually good. The page says I can filter but doesn't prove the filtered content is high quality.

gut_reaction: My friends want $20-cover bars. I want free things that are actually good. If this delivers that, I'd use it every week.
unanswered_questions: What's the typical shortlist quality when filtered to free only? How many free events are in the system currently?
share_trigger: Yes, I'd share with all my AmeriCorps colleagues who have the same budget constraints.

name: Isabel Torres
clarity_response: An app that shortlists personalized NYC event recommendations filtered to your budget, preferences, and schedule.
strongest_line: We filter so you don't have to.
weakest_section: The social proof section — all data from the founders' own interviews. That's research validation, not product validation.
what_feels_off: I tried Eventbrite's free filter and quality was wildly inconsistent. The page says this is better but doesn't explain how or why. That gap is where my skepticism lives.
objections: High skepticism. Beta product. No proof the free event quality is better than Eventbrite. I moved here for the city but I've been burned by apps that promise good free content and deliver junk.
gut_reaction: The concept is right but I need evidence before I trust it. I'm financially stressed and can't afford to waste time on bad event recommendations.
unanswered_questions: What makes this categorically better than Eventbrite's free filter for quality? Is there any editorial curation layer on free events?
share_trigger: Only after I've used it and verified the free event quality.
